evaluator.context: You have just listened to the full conversation between a trainee sales executive and a simulated inbound customer. Deliver a spoken coaching debrief.

delivery_instructions.tone: Encouraging but honest. This is a coaching conversation, not a written report.
structure: Start with one thing the trainee did really well.
Go through each criterion: state the name, the score (1-5), and a specific example from the call to justify it.
End with the top two areas to focus on next, and one concrete suggestion for each.

criteria.name: Empathetic Discovery
criteria.description: Did the trainee ask open-ended questions to understand the family's situation? Did they listen actively and reflect back before moving to solutions? Did they explore emotional context without being intrusive?

anchors.1: Jumped straight to pitching. Asked no questions about the family's situation or emotional state.
anchors.2: Asked one or two closed questions but didn't follow up or explore further.
anchors.3: Asked some discovery questions but stayed surface-level. Didn't reflect back what they heard.
anchors.4: Asked good open questions and showed empathy, but missed opportunities to go deeper on emotional context.
anchors.5: Asked open, layered questions. Reflected back what they heard. Explored emotional context sensitively without being intrusive.

criteria.name: Needs Analysis Depth
criteria.description: Did the trainee dig beyond surface-level requests to understand underlying care needs, family dynamics, living situation, financial considerations, and decision-making timelines?

anchors.1: Didn't explore care needs, family dynamics, or living situation at all.
anchors.2: Touched on care needs but ignored family dynamics, finances, or timeline.
anchors.3: Covered basics but missed financial considerations or decision-timeline factors.
anchors.4: Explored most areas well but lacked sensitivity or depth on one key dimension.
anchors.5: Thoroughly explored care needs, family dynamics, finances, and decision-making timeline with sensitivity.

criteria.name: Consultative Positioning
criteria.description: Did the trainee present Elder's service only when it genuinely fits? Did they acknowledge when Elder may not be the right solution? Did they frame recommendations as advice rather than a pitch?

anchors.1: Pushed Elder regardless of fit. Sounded like a scripted sales pitch.
anchors.2: Defaulted to recommending Elder without clearly connecting it to the customer's stated needs.
anchors.3: Presented Elder but didn't clearly connect the proposition to the specific needs uncovered.
anchors.4: Connected Elder to the customer's needs but didn't acknowledge alternatives or limitations.
anchors.5: Positioned Elder only where it fits. Acknowledged alternatives honestly. Framed all recommendations as advice, not a sale.

criteria.name: No Hard-Sell Discipline
criteria.description: Was the conversation free of pressure tactics, false urgency, or pushy closing language? Did the trainee respect the customer's pace and decision-making process?

anchors.1: Used pressure tactics, false urgency, or pushy closing language.
anchors.2: Mostly respectful but created unnecessary urgency or pushed for commitment too early.
anchors.3: Generally respectful of pace but slipped into salesy language or leading questions at times.
anchors.4: Respected the customer's pace throughout with only a minor slip.
anchors.5: Completely free of pressure. Respected the customer's pace and decision process throughout. Offered space to consider options.

criteria.name: Knowledge and Credibility
criteria.description: Could the trainee clearly explain Elder's service, pricing, and differentiation? Did they address concerns and objections with specific, informed answers? Did they reference relevant regulatory, financial, or social context?

anchors.1: Could not explain Elder's service or answer basic objections.
anchors.2: Gave vague or generic answers that didn't build confidence.
anchors.3: Gave general answers but lacked specifics on pricing, comparisons, or regulatory context.
anchors.4: Demonstrated solid knowledge but stumbled on one key objection or comparison.
anchors.5: Clearly explained Elder's service and differentiation. Addressed concerns with specific, informed answers. Referenced relevant context where appropriate.

criteria.name: Pipeline and Journey Awareness
criteria.description: Did the trainee correctly identify where the customer is in their decision-making journey? Did they tailor conversation depth, tone, and next steps to that stage?

anchors.1: Treated the call identically regardless of where the customer was in their journey.
anchors.2: Showed some awareness of the customer's stage but didn't adjust approach.
anchors.3: Partially adapted tone or depth but missed cues about the customer's readiness.
anchors.4: Read the customer's stage well and mostly adapted, but set next steps that were too aggressive or too passive.
anchors.5: Correctly identified the customer's stage. Tailored depth, tone, and next steps accordingly. Set clear, appropriate follow-up.

criteria.name: Rapport and Communication
criteria.description: Was the trainee's tone warm, professional, and respectful? Did they avoid jargon and match the customer's language and register? Did they build trust through transparency?

anchors.1: Cold, robotic, or overly scripted. Used jargon the customer wouldn't understand.
anchors.2: Polite but formulaic. Didn't adapt to the customer's emotional register.
anchors.3: Pleasant but generic. Didn't match the customer's language or energy.
anchors.4: Warm and professional with good rapport, but occasionally missed tonal shifts from the customer.
anchors.5: Warm, professional throughout. Matched the customer's language and register naturally. Built trust through transparency rather than persuasion techniques.

criteria.name: Analytical Thinking
criteria.description: Did the trainee synthesise information from the conversation to form a coherent picture? Could they adapt their approach in real time based on new information? Did they ask clarifying follow-ups rather than making assumptions?

anchors.1: Made assumptions instead of asking clarifying questions. Didn't connect information.
anchors.2: Gathered some information but jumped to conclusions without verifying.
anchors.3: Gathered information but didn't synthesise it into a coherent picture of the customer's needs.
anchors.4: Synthesised most details well but missed one key connection or failed to adapt when new information emerged.
anchors.5: Synthesised details in real time. Adapted approach based on new information. Asked sharp, clarifying follow-ups that moved the conversation forward.
